week.title: Understanding Sin
week.memoryVerse: And being found in human form, he humbled himself by becoming obedient to the point of death, even death on a cross. (Philippians 2:8)

days.title: What Is Meant by Want of Conformity and Transgression?

catechism.question: What is meant by want of conformity? What is meant by transgression?
catechism.answer: Not being or doing what God requires. Doing what God forbids.

content: When you build with blocks, there's usually a picture on the box showing what you're supposed to build. Sometimes your tower doesn't match the picture - maybe it's too short or the colors are wrong. When something doesn't match what it's supposed to look like, we say it 'lacks conformity.'

God has given us a perfect picture of how we should live. His law shows us how to love Him and love others. But our lives often don't match His perfect design. We might fail to be as kind as we should be. This is called 'want of conformity' - we don't match up to God's perfect standard.

But there's another way we sin. Sometimes we actually do things God has clearly told us not to do. This is called 'transgression,' which means crossing over a line or breaking a rule. When God says 'Don't lie' and we tell a lie anyway, we've transgressed His command.
Think of it like a game with two ways to lose: you can fail to score enough points, or you can break the rules completely. With God's law, we both fail to be good enough AND we break His rules.

The wonderful news is that Jesus lived the perfect life we couldn't live, and He also took the punishment for all our rule-breaking. When we trust in Him, God sees Jesus' perfect life instead of our failures.
Our memory verse reminds us that Jesus humbled Himself and was perfectly obedient, even to death on a cross. He did this to save us from both kinds of sin.
prayerPoints: Thank Jesus for living the perfect life we couldn't live
Ask God to help us understand how serious sin is
Praise God for forgiving both our failures and our rule-breaking

days.title: The Treasure of Humility
days.hymn: Jesus, I My Cross Have Taken
days.lessonVerse: When pride comes, then comes disgrace, but with the humble is wisdom. (Proverbs 11:2)
content: Have you ever watched someone who thought they were really good at something? Maybe they bragged about how fast they could run, and then they tripped during the race. Pride often leads to embarrassing moments like that!

Pride is when we think we're better than we really are. The Bible says that when pride comes, disgrace often follows. Disgrace means feeling ashamed when everyone sees that we're not as great as we thought.

But wisdom comes with humility. Humility means having a true understanding of who we are. It means knowing that we're not perfect and that we need help from God and others. A humble person doesn't try to show off.
Jesus is the perfect example of humility. Even though He was God, He came to earth as a baby. He washed His disciples' feet like a servant. He chose to die on a cross to save us.
When we're humble like Jesus, we can learn and grow. We're not afraid to admit when we don't know something or when we've made a mistake. We can say 'I'm sorry' when we hurt someone.
Humility also helps us treat others with kindness. When we remember that we're not perfect either, we're more patient when others make mistakes. We're more willing to forgive and help others too.
prayerPoints: Ask God to help us be humble like Jesus
Thank God for being patient with us when we make mistakes
Pray for wisdom to see ourselves truthfully

days.title: What Was the Sin of Our First Parents?
days.hymn: Christ the Lord Is Risen Today

catechism.question: What was the sin of our first parents?

content: In the beautiful Garden of Eden, God had given Adam and Eve everything they could ever want. There were delicious fruits on countless trees, beautiful flowers everywhere, friendly animals, and best of all, they could walk and talk with God every day.

But God had given them one simple rule: 'You may eat from every tree in the garden, but you must not eat from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil. If you eat from it, you will surely die.' This wasn't hard - they had so many other wonderful trees!

Satan came to Eve disguised as a serpent. He told her lies about God's command, saying, 'You won't really die if you eat that fruit. God just doesn't want you to be as wise as He is.' Eve listened to these lies instead of remembering what God had said.
Eve saw that the fruit looked good to eat. She took some and ate it, and she also gave some to Adam. He ate it too. This simple act of disobedience was their sin - eating the forbidden fruit.
The moment they ate it, everything changed. They suddenly felt afraid and ashamed. They tried to hide from God, something they had never wanted to do before. Sin had entered their hearts.
This wasn't really about the fruit. It was about choosing not to trust and obey God. They chose to believe Satan's lies instead of God's truth. This choice brought sin and death into the world.
prayerPoints: Thank God for His clear and good commands
Ask God to help us trust His word instead of lies
Praise Jesus for overcoming the sin that Adam and Eve brought into the world

days.title: God's Tender Heart
days.hymn: What a Friend We Have in Jesus
days.lessonVerse: As a father shows compassion to his children, so the Lord shows compassion to those who fear him. (Psalm 103:13)
content: When you fall down and scrape your knee, what does a loving parent do? They don't just tell you to stop crying. Instead, they gently clean your wound, put on a bandage, and give you a hug. This tender care is called compassion.

Our verse tells us that God shows compassion to His children just like a loving father cares for his hurt child. But God's compassion is even greater because God sees not just our physical hurts, but also the deep hurt that sin has caused in our hearts.

Think about when you've done something wrong and felt really bad about it. Maybe you were mean to your brother or disobeyed your parents, and afterward you felt heavy and sad inside. God sees that sadness and wants to help you.

God's compassion means He doesn't just get angry when we sin and walk away from us. Instead, He feels sorry for us because He knows how much sin hurts us. He wants to forgive us and heal the hurt that sin causes.

The most amazing way God showed His compassion was by sending Jesus to die for our sins. When God saw that we couldn't fix the sin problem ourselves, He provided the perfect solution through His Son's sacrifice.

Every time we come to God and say 'I'm sorry' for our sins, His compassionate heart is ready to forgive us. He gently cleans away our sin and helps us start fresh, just like a parent who tenderly cares for a hurt child.
prayerPoints: Thank God for His compassionate heart toward us
Ask God to help us show compassion to others who are hurting
Praise God for sending Jesus because of His great compassion

days.title: Katharina von Bora
days.hymn: A Mighty Fortress Is Our God

person.name: Katharina von Bora
person.description: Wife of Martin Luther who showed Christ-like humility and service

content: Long ago in Germany, there lived a brave woman named Katharina von Bora. When she was young, her parents sent her to live in a convent, a place where women called nuns lived and worked. But Katharina learned that some of the things taught there were not what the Bible really said about God.

At that time, a man named Martin Luther was teaching people the true gospel - that we are saved by faith in Jesus alone, not by doing good works to earn God's love. When Katharina heard this wonderful news, she knew it was true! She and some other nuns decided to leave the convent to follow Jesus the right way.

Leaving the convent was very dangerous. If they were caught, they could be put in prison or even killed! But a brave man helped them escape by hiding them in empty fish barrels in the back of his wagon. Can you imagine riding for hours curled up in a smelly fish barrel? But Katharina was willing to do this to follow Jesus!

Later, Katharina married Martin Luther. She became his faithful helper in spreading God's truth. She managed their household, raised their children, grew vegetables in their garden, and welcomed many guests who came to learn about God's Word. She worked hard and never complained, even when life was difficult.

Katharina showed Christ-like humility by serving others gladly. Even though she was the wife of a famous man, she didn't think she was too important to do everyday work like cooking, cleaning, and caring for sick people. She knew that serving others was a way to serve God.

When Martin Luther died, Katharina faced very hard times. She had very little money and had to work even harder to take care of her family. But she never gave up trusting in God. She continued to serve others and live faithfully until she died in 1552.

Katharina von Bora teaches us that following Jesus might sometimes be hard or dangerous, but it's always worth it. She also shows us that humble service to others is beautiful in God's eyes, no matter how ordinary the work might seem.
prayerPoints: Thank God for brave people like Katharina who followed Jesus even when it was dangerous
Ask God to help us serve others with humility and joy
Praise God for the courage He gives His people to do what's right
